brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study was to determine the effect of kefir, a natural probiotic, on appetite in healthy subjects. A randomized, single-blind and 3-intervention crossover trial included 22 healthy and normal-weight (BMI 18.5-25 kg/m2) females aged 21-24 years. All participants were submitted to three different breakfasts: a low GI and milk content (LGI-Milk), a low GI and kefir content (LGI-Kefir), and a high GI and kefir content (HGI-Kefir), with a 1-week washout period between meals. Appetite ratings was measured at 0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 150 and 180 minutes. At the end of three hours, participants were served ad libitum lunch meal. Then, the foods eaten at lunch were recorded and their energy and nutrient analysis was calculated.

primary_outcome.description: Subjective assessment of appetite sensations was performed by using a visual analog scale (VAS) composed of lines (of 100 mm in length) with words anchored at each end, expressing the most positive and the most negative rating. VAS ratings were measured by using a question "How hungry do you feel? (not at all hungry - as hungry as I ever felt)" at time points 0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 150 and 180 minutes, and hunger rating was quantified as AUC (mm x min), which was calculated according to the trapezoidal rule by using those VAS scores. Total scale score changes in a range of 0-100. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

Subjective assessment of appetite sensations was performed by using a visual analog scale (VAS) composed of lines (of 100 mm in length) with words anchored at each end, expressing the most positive and the most negative rating. VAS ratings were measured by using a question "How full do you feel? (not at all full - totally full)" at time points 0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 150 and 180 minutes, and fullness rating was quantified as AUC (mm x min), which was calculated according to the trapezoidal rule by using those VAS scores. Total scale score changes in a range of 0-100. Higher values represent a better outcome.

Subjective assessment of appetite sensations was performed by using a visual analog scale (VAS) composed of lines (of 100 mm in length) with words anchored at each end, expressing the most positive and the most negative rating. VAS ratings were measured by using a question "How strong is your desire to eat? (very weak - very strong)" at time points 0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 150 and 180 minutes, and desiring to eat was quantified as AUC (mm x min), which was calculated according to the trapezoidal rule by using those VAS scores. Total scale score changes in a range of 0-100. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

Subjective assessment of appetite sensations was performed by using a visual analog scale (VAS) composed of lines (of 100 mm in length) with words anchored at each end, expressing the most positive and the most negative rating. VAS ratings were measured by using a question "How much do you think you can eat? (no food at all - a large amount of food)" at time points 0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 150 and 180 minutes, and prospective food consumption was quantified as AUC (mm x min), which was calculated according to the trapezoidal rule by using those VAS scores. Total scale score changes in a range of 0-100. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

The separate visual analog scale components such as hunger, fullness, desire to eat and prospective food consumption were combined to produce an additional measure termed 'composite appetite score'. This validated average appetite score was calculated for each time point 0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 150 and 180 minutes using the following equation: [(hunger + desire to eat + prospective food consumption + (100 - fullness)]/4 Total scale score changes in a range of 0-100. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

arm_group.description: Low glycemic index and milk content (LGI-Milk) breakfast as a test meal
Low glycemic index and kefir content (LGI-Kefir) breakfast as a test meal
High glycemic index and kefir content (HGI-Kefir) breakfast as a test meal

intervention.description: This test meal with low glycemic index and milk were served as a breakfast after 12-hours fasting and participants were asked to consume the meal in full, within 15 min.
In crossover design, this test meal with low glycemic index and kefir was served as a breakfast to compare the LGI-Milk Breakfast.
In crossover design, this test meal with high glycemic index and kefir was served as a breakfast to compare the LGI-Milk Breakfast and the LGI-Kefir Breakfast.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy
- Normal-weight (BMI 18.5-25 kg/m2)
- Female
- 21-24 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Following an energy-restricted diet during the last three months
- Change in body weight >5 kg during the last three months
- Lack of appetite
- Physician-diagnosed conditions or medications that influence metabolism
- Having any chronic diseases such as diabetes, hypertension etc.
- Smoking
- Practicing endurance sports
- Having difficulties with swallowing/eating
- Hypersensitivity for the food products under study
- Being a vegan
- Pregnant or lactating
